snippet: The recently discovered fly, Euryplatea nanaknihali, is less than two-hundredths of an inch long — one-fifteenth the size of a housefly and one-fifth that of fruit fly.
abstract: Dr Brian V Brown study in the Annals of the Entomological Society of America identifies the world's smallest known fly, a native of Thailand known as Euryplatea nanaknihali; species, which is two-hundredths of an inch long, lays its eggs in the heads of ants.
lead_paragraph: The recently discovered fly, Euryplatea nanaknihali, is less than two-hundredths of an inch long — one-fifteenth the size of a housefly and one-fifth that of fruit fly.

headline.print_headline: Hardly a Speck of a Fly, But Able to Decapitate
headline.seo: Hardly a Speck of a Fly, But Able to Decapitate Ants
headline.main: Hardly a Speck of a Fly, but Able to Decapitate
